sp.p: Daredevil, Dog, Coward, draw thy Sword and rescue me.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: I am terrified, amaz'd; some Judgment for my Sins is fallen upon me; alas, I am in Bonds too! Have mercy on my Soul, and don't slay me, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Damnation! Blinded! Rascals, Villains, Ruffians! Murder!

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p:
Oh
Daredevil, Daredevil
, what will become of thee!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: This Generosity makes good thy Character,
That thou art the bravest Man, and truest Friend.
How shall I deserve this from thee?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I should be unjust, both to my self, and the dear Mem'ry of thy Noble Brother, whose Friendship was so dear to me, should my true Sword be idle in thy Cause. Besides, the Love which I profess to Porcia, tells me a Rival must not tamely carry her.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: She is thy Right: My dying Brother, her soon-forgotten Husband,
But thy remember'd Friend, with his last Breath thus told me;
I have a Friend, Gratian, the Man my Heart
Has cherisht most; we from our Youth were Rivals
For my dear Porica: tell him, if I die,
I left her to him, as the dearest Legacy
I ●ould bequeath: Bid him be tender of her,
For she'll deserve it from him.— Would she did.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Heav'n knows, it is my Curse, spite of her Scorn, to love her even to Madness; nor shall this Man of War, this French-bred Hero, win her with nothing but his Cap and Feather: I wonder he's not come yet.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I have heard the Man is Gallant; but in honesty,
As thou art my Friend, I wish thou wouldst hear good Counsel▪

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thine must be Noble.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I'd have thee think no more of this proud Woman.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I wish 'twere possible.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Their Sex is one gross Cheat; their only Study
How to deceive, betray, and ruine Man:
They have it by Tradition from their Mothers,
Which they improve each day, and grow more exquisite.
Their Painting, Patching, all their Chamber-arts,
And Publick Affectations, are but Tricks
To draw fond Men into that Snare, their Love.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Would this could cure mine.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: When w'are caught fast, 'tis then they shew their Natures,
Grow haughty, proud, to vex the Wretch th'ave conquer'd;
Tho the same Hour they glance abroad for new ones.
Let but a Woman know y'are once her Slave,
Give her once Testimony that you love her,
She'll always be thy Torment, Jilt, design,
And practice Ends upon thy honest Nature,
So strong is their Antipathy to Truth.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: But let a Fool—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Oh give 'em but a Fool,
A senseless, noise, gay, bold, bristling Blockhead,
A Rascal with a Feather, and Cravat-string,
No Brains in's Head; a vain, pert, empty Rogue,
That can prune, dance, lisp, or lie very much,
Th'are lost for ever: They'll give all they have
To Fools, or for 'em.—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: But, my Friend, this granted,
Grant Porica this, and more, as she's the Relict
Of thy dear Brother, and my valu'd Friend,
The Injury she brings upon thy Honour
Must not be slighted; and that's my Cause now.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: There thou o'recom'st me: Still our Men of Mettle
Delay their Time; the Day grows late; let's walk
Down by yon' Wall; may be they have mist the Place:
Besides, I fancy Company is coming this way, and we may be prevented.
Methinks I would not lose so fine a Morning, and do nothing.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh Lucrece, 'twas the Pangs of Jealousie, curst Jealousie, that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Where lodg'd you then last Night?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Here, in this House, my Cousin Porcia's House: I met her late last Night, just as I alighted, harrast with my Journey, and the Cause of it: Had she not took pity of me, Heav'n knows how my Perplexities would have disposed me!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: What, in this House?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Here, in this very House.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I'm glad I know it; I'll take such care, it shall not be long a Secret.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: The Garden opening thus upon the Fields, invited me to take the Morning-air here; for Sleep's a Guest that stays but little with me. Why sighest thou, Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I'm thinking why my Cousin Porcia should chuse this Residence.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p:
'Tis for a Lover,
Lucrece; Beaugard
courts her, a Friend and lewd Companion of my false Husband's.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I know him but too well.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Why, dost thou love him?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: So much, that I can neither eat, drink, nor sleep in peace, for the tormenting Thoughts of him.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: By Heav'ns, I pity thee. Oh have a care of Marriage, Lucrece, Marriage; 'twill be thy Bane, and ruine thee for ever. Marriage spoils Faces; How I look with Marriage!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I see no change.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: No change! I have not slept six Nights in peace since the curst Day I wedded.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Will then a Husband spoil ones Sleep so sadly?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: A Husband's, Lucrece, like his Wedding-Clothes,
Worn gay a Week, but then he throws 'em off,
And with 'em too the Lover: Then his Days
Grow gay abroad, and his Nights dull at home:
He lies whole Months by thy poor longing Side
Heavy and useless, comes faint and loth to Bed,
Turns him about, grunts, snores: and that's a Husband.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Is Courtine such a one?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: 'Tis pain to tell thee the Life I 〈◊〉 with him.

He's colder to me, than Adamant to Fire; but let him loose amongst my Kitchen-Furniture, my Maids, never was seen so termagant a Towzer: He loves a nasty, foul-fed, fulsom Drab, and scorns the tender Joys my Arms invite him to. To be despis'd at that rate, so dishonour'd, makes me even curse the Chance that made me Woman: Would I had been any Creature else.— See yonder, yonder he comes: Thy Masque, thy Masque, dear Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Farewel; I'll away, and leave ye fairly both together.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What, fly thy ground, faint Soldier! How, another! Nay then 'twas nobly done, two to one had been odds else: Had it not pretty one?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Why, who are you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: E'en a wandring Knight, that have forsaken my Castle in the Country, and am come up to Town for Preferment truly.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: And one would think so proper, lusty, a well-made Fellow as you are should not be long out of Employment.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Dost thou know me, my Dearest?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then I am sure thou canst have no Exception against me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But suppose I had a mind to a little farther Acquaintance with you; what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why, then thou may'st reasonably suppose that I'll make no evil Use of thy good Inclinations; Faith there are very pretty Gardens hereabouts, let us commit a Trespass for once, break into one of 'em, and ●oll a Camomile-walk together this Morning.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Sir!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: She's coming already.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: If I should let you make advantage of my Weakness now, you would be false afterwards, forsake me, and break my heart.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Pretty fool! What innocent scruples she makes!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Have you no other Mistress already? have you no Engagements that will return hereafter upon your heart to my prejudice?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Shall I swear?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But han't you truly?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If I have, may that blew Mountain over our heads there, fall down and crush me like a pelted Toad.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: To shew you then that I desere your Faith—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What wilt thou shew me?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: A Face which I am not asham'd of, though you'l perhaps be scandaliz'd when you see it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The Devil take me if I am though, so it prove not very horrible indeed.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What think you then, Sir, is it such a one as you lookt for?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My own Wife!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Yes, thy unhappy Wife,
Thou false, deceitful, perjur'd, shamles Wretch:
Have I deserv'd this from thee?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pox confound her.—

div.stage: [Takes out a Book and falls to reading.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Is this the recompense of all my love?
Did I bestow my Fortune on thy▪ Wants,
Humble my self to be thy Dove-like Wife?
And is this all I'm worth?—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Wealth is a great
Provocative to am'rous heat
For what is worth in any thing,
But so much Money as 'twill bring?

Hudibras, Part the
2d, Canto
the First.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Patience direct me! have I wrought my Nature
To utmost sufferance, and most low contentment,
Set my poor heart to cares! have I been blest
With Children by thee, to be left with scorn,
Cast off, neglected, and abandon'd vilely?
Speak, is not this hard usage?—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Umph!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Umph! what's Umph!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Umph, that's I, Child; Umph is I, I, I, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Death! death and torments! Cut my wretched Throat, don't treat me thus: By Heaven I'le bear't no longer.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No more.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I have done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What do you at London!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Is it a fault to follow what I'm fond of!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Can't I enjoy my pleasures, take my freedoms, but you must come, and spoil the high season'd dish with your insipid whining senseless Jealousie?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Prethee forgive me.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where did you lodge last Night?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Here with a Kinswoman,
May be you know her not, her name is Porcia.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Death! Beaugard's Widow! now I am finely fitted.
What at this House?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: This very House, that Door
Opens into the Garden, let us walk there,
Won't you go with me Courtine?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Prethee do, Love.
Don't be thus cruel to me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Then promise one thing,
And may be my good nature shall be wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: I'le grant thee any thing; speak, try m'Obedience.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: then promise me, that during our abode
In this sweet Town, which I love very dearly,
That let me ramble, steer what course I will,
Keep what late hours, and as I please employ 'em,
That you'l be still, an humble, civil Doxy,
And pry into no secret to disturb me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Well, 'tis all granted.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: On then, I'le be dutiful.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Enter you first.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: No.—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Oh, then you'l forsake me;
You seek but opportunity again to leave me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Well, since I am trapt thus,
Like a poor Beast that wanted better pasture,
There is no Replevin, and I must to Pound.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: What in this House?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Here in this very House,
My Cousin Sylvia, Courtine's Jealous Wife,
Coming to Town, Lodg'd with her here last Night.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: No more, I guess the cause w'are disappointed.
Do thou go Gratian, Muster what Friends 'tis possible;
I'le try my Interest too; we'll storm your Fortress,
Enchanted Lady, though your Gyant guard it.

div.stage: Scene changes to the inside of a very fair House, adorned with rich Furniture and Lights.
Enter Ruff. with Beaug. and Dared.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Dogs! Rascals! Villains! how do you intend to deal with us?

sp.speaker: 1. Ruff.
sp.p: Much better than your language has deserv'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p:
Sirs for this noble usage, had I a Sword or Pistol about me, I would reward ye most amply.
[They all bow and withdraw.
A Plague of your Civility! where the Devil are we?

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Where are we quotha! why, we are in a Palace Man, prithee look about thee a little.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: By Heav'n here's a Paradise; hark Daredevil! Musick too!

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p:
I'le be hang'd if 'tis not a bawdy Dancing-School, some better Whores than ordinary designing a private
Ballum rancum
, have pitcht upon our two proper persons for the bus'ness; we are like to have a swinging time on't, Beaugard.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: A plague o' your Cowardise! you were whining and praying just now, and be hang'd to you.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: I praying! prithee be quiet Man, I never pray'd in my life, nor ever will pray: Praying quotha! that's a merry jest with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Impudent Poltroon! he said two dozen of Pater-Nosters within this half hour, and every jolt the Coach gave was afraid the Devil would have torn him to pieces.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Odd I like this contrivance very well: Look, Beaugard, what comes yonder? 'sheart two Devils in Petticoats, how my Guts shrink together!

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Heyday! Lady Blackamores! nay then we are certainly enchanted. What are you two, Maids of Honour to the Queen of Pomonkey? and is this one of her Palaces? Not a Word!—

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: How I long now to be familiar with one of those Sooty-fac'd Harlots! I would beget a chopping Black Son of a Whore upon her, in defiance to the Prince of Darkness.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: What another too of the same Complexion? this must be her Majesties Page.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: A Pimp, I'le warrant him; he's so very little, pert, and dapper, the Rogue looks as if he could im●●●ate himself through a Key-hole.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: Welcome thou best-lov'd Man of the fair World.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and what's the Service you have in order to Command me?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: My Orders are to lead you to repose in a Rich Bed prepared for Rest and Love.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: I said it was a Pimp, what a smooth-tongu'd little Rascal 'tis?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: A very pretty sort of an Amusement this: But prithee young Domine, why to Bed? 'tis but now Day, and the Sun newly risen; for I have not been a Bed all Night, my little Monster; I know how the time goes, Child.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Such are the Orders of the Power I serve.
For you are come a long unmeasurable Journey.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Dwaf.
sp.p: Drawn by wing'd Horses through the untract Air.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: A Pox upon thee for a little black lying well-instructed Rascal, but since it is the Custom of the place, and my last Night Fatigue requires it, I'le accept of the offer, and dispense with an hour or two of sleep to fit me for better exercise when I wake again.

div.stage: [Sits down in the Chair to be undrest.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Drawn by Wing'd Horses through the Air, said he! if this should be true now, what would become of us! Methought indeed the Coach whew'd it away a little faster than ordinary.

div.stage: [While Beaug. is undressing the two Black Women dance.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p:
A very notable Entertainment truly, and your little Black Lady-ships have tript it most featly.—
[The Wo. advance towards him.
What, and must you take charge of me now!— With all my heart. Daredevil farewel to thee; but that I am in hopes of a better, I'de invite thee for a Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Bedfellow, quotha! would I were a Bed with any Bedfellow that I was sure had but flesh and bones about him.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you are my charge.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: I hope your little Impship will be civil to me: pray, Sir, what place is this?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: A Chrystal Castle built by Enchantment in a Land unknown to any but the fair one that Commands it: The Spirits of the Air keep guard about it, and all obey her Charms.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Oh Lord! and what Religion is the Lady off?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: That's a secret, you'l know more hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dared.
sp.p: Lead on then: Now in the lower World whence I come lately, were this but known,
sp.l: How would the fate in Ballad be lamented,
Of Daredevil ●●e Atheist that's Enchanted.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: THese are your Men of Honour now: I never knew a blustering, roaring, swashing Spark, that, at the bottom, was good for any thing.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Your faux Braves always put on a shew of more Courage than ordinary; as your beggarly half-Gentlemen always wear tawdry finer Cloaths than their Fortune will afford 'em.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: But, to lye conceal'd in private in the House with her!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Dam' her, she's a Prostitute; has given her self already to his Arms.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Yet, I'll warrant you, she has an excuse for that too, if it be so; as, Alas! you know, Woman is but a weak Vessel.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: A Pox o' the weakness of her Vessel! Dam' her! Would my Sword were in her Throat! But will our Friends be ready?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Most punctually. It was an odd old Fellow, that, which we met with. Was he certainly Beaugard's Father?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No body can swear that, for his Mother was a Woman; but that merry conceited old Gentleman has the honour of it: he has the Title, but whose was the Property, that I dare not determine.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I hope he'll be as good as his word with us.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: It will not be amiss if it prove so. See, here he comes too.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You lie, you Dog; you Scanderbeg Varlet, you lie. Do not I know that he sate up all Night with a Consort of Whore-masters and Harlots; and have you the impudence to tell me he is not at home? Do not I know, you Villain, that, after a Debauch, he will out-snore a Fleet-street-Cons●able and all his Watch, for six hours; and dare you tell me, he is not at home, you Caterpillar?

sp.speaker: Fourb.
sp.p:
Upon the word of a true
Valet de Chambre
, Sir, I deal sincerely and honestly with you.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: No more to be said: But, Sirrah, do you take notice in his behalf, and tell him, he shall pay for this; pay for it, do you hear you Mongril? Fob me off with ten stinking Guinnies, when I had lost a hundred! Fiends and Furies, I'll not bear it. Good morrow my little Thunder-bolts! What say you, my tiny brace of Blunderbusses? can I be serviceable? shall we about the business while it is practicable? hah?—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Have you considered of it throughly, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Trouble thy head no farther; I'll do't, my Darling.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Have you considered, Sir, that she is your Son's Mistress?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: So much the better still; I'll swinge her the stoutlier, for allenating his Affections from his natural Father.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: But suppose you should meet him too there in her defence, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Still better and better, and better for that very reason; for I would swinge him too with much fatherly Discipline, and teach him the duty which a Son, with a great deal of Money, ows an honest old Daddy, that has none.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Very piously resolved, this; that's the truth on't. But, Sir, I would have you satisfied, into the bargain, that this will be no trifling matter. No Boys Play, old Tilbury.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Boys Play, Sir; Sir, I can sight, Sir: though I am an old fellow, I have a Fox by my side here, that will snarl upon occasion. Boys Play! I don't understand your Boys Play, Sir—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I would not have you take my plainness ill, Sir: I only hinted it, to deal with you according to an old fashion of sincerity which I profess, Sir. I hope you are not offended at it.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Then, to rectifie all mistakes, let us fairly have a Breakfast,
hoc Momento
. I have a sort of gnawing Courage, that when it is provok'd, always gives me a Stomack to a savoury Bit, and a cheerful Bottle. I hate to be run through the Guts, with nothing in 'em to keep the Wind out.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Very well propos'd, I think; for we have more Fiends to meet us at a Tavern hard by here, where we Intend to wish our Enterprise well in a bonny Bottle or two, and then about it as cheerfully as we can.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Very well said, that: This is a pretty fellow, I'll warrant him. Now, if my Rebel be run through the Midriff in this business, I am the next Heir at Law, and the two thousand Pounds a year is my own, declaro. Come along my little Spit-●res.
Nous allons.
Brave strippons.
Sans scavoir on Nous allons.
Six Bumpers in a hand to him that drills the first Whore-Master through the small Guts.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: We'll pledge it heartily, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
You are both my honest Boys, my best Children: march along then, bravely and boldly.— I must borrow Money of these Fellows before I part with 'em.
Nous allons, Brave strippons
,

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh the unconscionable Importunity of an unsavoury, plegmatick, cold, insipid Wife! By this good day, she has kiss'd me till I am downright sick; I have had so much of her, that I shall have no stomach to the Sex again this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: My Dearest, pray my Dearest, don't thus leave me: by this kind kiss I beg is.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, the Devil!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Look kindly on me; speak to me.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Plague intollerable!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, I love you with such fondness! Pray speak.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Why? an't you well?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, there's a sudden faintness comes o'er my Spirits! Oh, I'm very sick! Leave me, if thou lov'st me, stand off, and give me Air; I die else. Ohh!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I'll kiss thee then to life again.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Stand off, I say; I'll not be stifled! Murder! Help! Murder! Help!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Ill natur'd Tyrant!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Good natur'd Devils! Kiss, i'th' Devil's name!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Come near me, Husband.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come not near me, Wife. How am I tortur'd!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: You must be kind; indeed, my dear, you must.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, by your good leave, I sha' not,— Damnation!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: You long to be rid of me again.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That I do most mightily; but how to bring it about, if I know, I am a Rascal. Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What's the matter, Dearee?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, I am sick again of the sudden! Give me the Chair there: Oh! my Heart beats, and my Head swims! Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Alas, I fear y'are very sick indeed! if my poor Lovee should die, what would become of me!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A Plague o' your whining! Would I were well out of the House once!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Shall I fetch thee some Cordial, my dearest Love, my Joy? Speak to me; shall I?—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ay if thou wilt, my Jewel. Jewel quotha!— what a plagu's this: Hush, is she gone?— Now for a convenient Balcone to venture the breaking of a Neck at.—

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: With me, Sweetheart; thy business?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: A Lady, Sir, that dog'd you hither this Morning—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A Lady!—

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, a Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Hist: Get you in, you little Monkey; skip, sculk, or you'll spoil all else.— Here's the blessed comfort of a Wife again now:— Oh, oh!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: How is't, my Blessing? Here, take this: Heaven guard thee.!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: From thy confounded troublesome Company, if it be possible.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: How is't, my Dearee?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If I had a little more on't, Dearee.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I'll see what's left, my Joy.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Do, prithee do, my Joy then. Joy in the Devil's name.
[Ex. Sylv.
Hist, Sirrah Page, come hither.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Is your Lady gone, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes: But what News of the other Lady, my trusty Mercury?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: She's now below, Sir; and desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Is she young? handsom?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I can't tell that, Sir; but she's rare and fine.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Are her Cloaths rich?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Oh Sir, all Gold and Silver; with a deep Point
Thingum Thangum
over her Shoulders: and then she smells as sweet as my Ladies Dressing-Box.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Fly little Spright, and tell her, I'm impatient: tell her, I'll wait on her within a moment: tell her—

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: But Sir—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Be gone, be gone, you Knave, or you'll be caught else. Oh!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Here's all that's left, my Heart.

sp.speaker: Court.
Sylv.
sp.p: What ails my Life?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, I have a horrid tremor upon my Heart! 'tis the old Palpitation I us'd to be troubl'd with, return'd again. Oh, if I were but—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Where, Love?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh! but in a condition to go abroad, there is an able Fellow of my Acquaintance, that always us'd to relieve me in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Where does he live? I'll take a Coach my self, and go to him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The Devil take me if I know.— Oh! 'tis a vast way off.— Oh! now it kills me again.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I shall not think it so, when it is my duty.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That's but too kind, my Sweetest; though, if I had but one Bottle of his Elixir.—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: How is it call'd?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Specimen Vitae.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Specimen Vitae?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Ay,
Specimen Vitae
: 'tis a damn'd hard name, but it is very good.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Where is't he lives then? Prithee let me go thither.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis a horrid way off! Besides, it would trouble me now, in this condition, to be so long without thee.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Prithee let me go.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why, 'tis as far as Grubb-street Child, as Grubb-street?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I'll be back again instantly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I had rather, indeed, thou shouldst go thy self, than send a Messenger, because the business will be done more carefully.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: How's the Direction then?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
In Grubb-street Child, at the Sign of the Sun and Phaenix, I think it is, there lives a Chymist; ask for him, and in my name desire a Bottle of his
Specimen Vitae
. Oh!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Specimen Vitae?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Ay,
Specimen Vitae
— I'll try in the mean time if I can walk about the Room, and divert the terrour of my Fits.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Heavens bless my dearest Dearee.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Thank you, my only Joy.— Would in the Devil's Name she were gone once, and had her Guts full of that Quack's
Specimen Vitae
.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: You'll be careful of your self, Child?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: As careful as I can, Child.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Gud b'w'y Courtee.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: B'w'y my Sylvee.— Oh, oh!
Is she gone?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where's the Lady?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Here; just entring up the back Stairs.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Madam, this Honour done your worthless Servant—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Heart, I had forgot my Wages. Pray Courtee, kiss me before I go.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Confound her, Come again! Oh, my Love! I have made hard shift to crawl to the Door here.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Who's that behind you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nothing but a Page, come to know if I wanted any thing. A Plague of her Hawks eyes!—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Gud b'w'y my dearest Love.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Gud b'w'y my Joy.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Nay, give me another. B'w'y Courtee.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: B'w'y Sylvee.— So, is she gone again?— The Devil take me, if thou interruptest me any more.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is that your Lady, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes; but I hope you'll not think the worse of me, pretty One, for keeping a Wife Company now and then, for want of better.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can you be so kind, Sir, not to forget me? Do you remember me still, Captain?

sp.speaker: Courts.
sp.p: Remember thee, Child! Is it possible for that Face to be ever blotted out of my Memory!— Though, the Devil eat me, if ever I saw it before, to the best of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where is your Lady gone Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
To Grubb-street, Jewel, for some
Specimen Vitae
.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Specimen Vitae
, Sir! Oh dear, what's that?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Oh, come but quietly into the next Room, and I will shew thee what
Specimen vitae
is presently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You may, perhaps think ● range of this freedom I take with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not in the least, Child; it shews thy Generosity.— I love her now, for understanding her business, and coming close to the matter quickly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But, Sir, presuming on your Quondam Favours to me, I am come to beg your Advice in a matter of Law, which I am at present involv'd in: and if you please—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: To retire a little in private?— Oh, thou couldst not have pick'd out such another Man for thy purpose: I am, may be, the best Lawyer in the World for Chamber-practice. And if I do not find out the Merits of thy Cause as soon as—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Really, you are so good natur'd—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Grubb-street and
Specimen Vitae
, quotha! He that has the Palpitation of the Heart, and an Armful of this won't cure him, let him die upon a Dung-hill, and be buried in a Ditch, I say.— This is the rarest Adventure.

div.stage: The SCENE changes to a Bed-Chamber.
Enter Beaugard in, as Dressing himself.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Heigho! Heigho! Boy, Imp, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: Here: Your pleasure? What's your pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: What is't o'Clock, Boy?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: Sir, in your World, by Computation, I guess it may be Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: A very pretty little Rascal, this; and a very extraordinary way of Proceeding, I am treated withal here: I have been abed, 'tis true, but the Devil a wink of sound Rest came near my Senses all the while; but broken Slumbers, Dreams, Starts, and sprawling from one side to the other, in hopes the fair Unknown that keeps this Castle might have been so good natur'd to have given a Stranger a Visit. This can be no less than some Romantick design of the little Fairy, that threatned she would cheat the Widow of me:— Now will I, for once, if she does attempt me, put on that monstrous Vertue, called Self-denial, and be damnably constant.— What, Musick again! This is a merry Region, I'll say that for it, where ever it be, Boy!

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: Did you call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: My Cloaths, Monster; my Vestments: I hate a Dis-habiliee mortally: I long to be rigg'd, that I may be fit for Action, if Occasion should present it self.

lg.head: A SONG.
lg.l: Welcom Mortal to this place,
Where smiling Fate did send thee:
Snatch thy happy Minutes, as they pass;
Who knows how few attend thee!
Floods of Ioy about thee roul,
And flow in endless measure.
Dip thy Wishes deep, and fill thy Soul
With Draughts of every Pleasure.
Feast thy Heart with Love's Desire,
Thy Eyes with Beauties Charms:
With Imaginations fan the Fire.
Then stifle it in thy Arms.
For, since Life's a slippery Guest,
Whose Flight can't be prevented;
Treat it, whilst it stays here, with the best,
And then 'twill go contented.
Come you that attend on our Goddesses Will,
And sprinkle the Ground
With Perfumes around;
Shew him your Duty, and shew us your Skill.

div.stage: Enter four Black Women, that dance to the same Measure of the Song, and sprinkle Sweets.

lg.l: Circle him with Charms,
And raise in his Heart
Such Alarms,
As Cupid ne'er wrought by the Pow'r of his Dart.
Fill all his Veins with a tender desire,
And then shew a Beauty to set 'em a fire;
Till kind panting Breasts to his Wound she apply,
Then on those white Pillows of Love let him die.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p:
Faith, and with all my heart; for I am weary of the lingring Disease, and long to taste my Mortality most mightily. Hah! A Banquet too, usher'd in by a couple of Cupids! Pretty innocent Contrivance! Well, here's no fear of starving, that's one comfort.
Two Cupids run in a Table furnish'd.
Now, my dear Musicians, would ye be but as good as your word, and shew me the Beauty you have so prepared me for!— But then, my Widow! my Dear, Generous, Noble-hearted Widow ● She that loves Liberty as I do. She that defies Matrimony as I do too. Shall I turn Recreant, and be false to her? Ah
Dardevill, Dardevill
! How I want thee to help me out in this Case of Conscience a little!

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Beaugard, Where art thou?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Ah dear Damnation! I was just now heartily wishing for thee.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Such News! Such Tidings! Such a Discovery!

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Hah! What's the matter, Man?—

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Only six and fifty Virgins apiece for us, that's all; pretty little blushing opening Buds, you Rogue, that never had so much as a blast of Masculine Breath upon them yet.— What's here? A Banquet ready● Nay, then I am satisfied. Never were Heroes so inchanted as we are.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: But where are the Virgins, Dardevill? the Virgins!

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: There's only one of'em, Child ● only one;— but such a one, my Souldier.—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Is there but one then?

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: That's no matter, Man; I'll be contented till thou hast done with her: I hate a new Conveniency that was never practised upon; 'tis like a new Shooe that was never worn, wrings and hurts ones Foot basely and scurvily. I love my ease, I.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: But is she very Lovely?

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Such a Swinger, you Dog! she'll make thy Heart bound like a Tennis Ball, at the sight of her: with a Majestick stately Shape and Motion.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: A Lovely, Angelical, Commanding Face.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: By Heavens.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: With two Triumphant, Rolling, Murdering Eyes, that swear at you ev'ry time you look upon her.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Stand off, stand off, I say; she's mine this Minute. But then again, my Widow!— Hah!— Mask'd too; when the Devil shall I see a Woman with her own natural Face again? Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Be pleas'd, Sir, to repose your self a little; there is a small Account, Sir, to be adjusted betwixt you and I. Where are my Servants? Who is it waits there?

div.stage: [Several Men Vizarded, and Arm'd, appear at the Doors.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: What the Devil can be the meaning of this now? I am not to be murdered, I hope, after all this Ceremony and Preparation.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Murder'd, in the Devil's Name? Here is great fear of being murder'd, truly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come Sir, sit down Sir.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Madam, I'll obey you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I doubt not, Sir, but, since your coming hither,
You are much surpris'd, and wonder at your Treatment.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: So, now the Fardle's opened, we shall see what is in it.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Madam, 'thas been so very highly generous.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That you are prepar'd with Complements to pay me for it.
But, Sir, such Coyn's Adulterate and Base:
I must have honest Dealing from your Heart.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Swear to her, swear to her a little, Man; pour out a Bushel of Oaths upon her instantly: Swear, swear, if thou wilt do any good upon her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know my Rival.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis so, just so, just as I thought, my poor widow will run a damnable hazard of losing this sweet Person of mine, if I do not take abundance of care in the business. Here are Rogues on each hand, with Blunderbusses too: I shall be ravish'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: She, by her Arts,
And the good fortune to have first attempted it,
I know, 's possess'd already of your Heart.
But know too, I'm a Woman loath Refusal.
Scornful Refusal—

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Swear to her, I tell thee: That ever a Fellow should lose all this time for an insignificant Oath or two!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Or, if my Fortune,
Which is not despicable, prove too weak
An Argument to tell you I deserve you;
Yet I have this to boast, I ne'er conceal'd my self,
Either for Shame or Ends; but rather chose
To run the Risque of being deny'd your Love,
Than win it by base Artifice and Practices.
What think you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Hah!—
That, Madam, I'm most miserable,
Unless—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your Widow Porcia, Sir, your Widow.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Madam, I must confess—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well:

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: That I love her, and will for ever.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Death! Do you confess it too?
See you not here yourself within my power,
And dare you still confess you love that Creature?
Thus far I've kept my Word, I've cross'd her Stratagems.
You are here my Pris'ner, and by what is past,
You ought to think me capable of more.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: If this Fellow would but swear a little, all this might be rectifi'd.
Madam, to my own knowledge—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Fool, stand off.
I'm sensible that you are the loveliest Creature
My Eyes e'er gaz'd on; but—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But what?—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: I'm sure
You'ld yourself scorn, nor think me worth your Heart,
Could I be faithless, could I be unconstant.
Pity me, fair One; yet, methinks this Hand—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Should send a Dagger to thy ungrateful Heart.
fly Heav'n, I'll never bear it—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: Madam,
Could you but throw some favour on your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: By all the fury in a Woman's Heart,
I'll be reveng'd on his. Make ready, Slaves,
To do your Office—

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: Madam—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, your Ladyship may do your pleasure; you may command half a dozen of Bullets through my Pericranium, if you have a mind to have your Beauty spoke well of by the Criticks of Holborn, that once a Month swarm at their Windows to spy handsom Faces: Upon that consideration you may murder a poor constant Monster if you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Still am I scorn'd then.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Would you kill me barbarously?
Sure those sweet Eyes could not see such a Sight.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No, take your Life, and with't this satisfaction;
Porcia scorns you, as much as you do me:
And, till thou suest upon thy humble Knees
To me for Pity, Porcia shall despise thee.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Madam, I swear!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: By all those Beauties.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be gone, for ever fly this. Ah h!—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Death, Damnation, Devils! How came I hither? Beaugard!

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: Friend Courtine! Speak Man: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Damnation! Jilted, cho●s'd, betrayed!—

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: A Midwife! Run for a Midwife, run for some good Woman.
Oh Madam, an Accident.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: A Midwife!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heavens! a Midwife!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, Friend, a Midwife. I am sweetly manag'd, I— I thought I had been in private here, in this House, with a civil Person of good Reputation, and it proves a damn'd trappanning Strumpet. Just in the middle of all our good Understanding together, she fetches a great Shreik, and roars out for a Midwife: The Drab is full gone with Bastard, and swears I am the Father of it.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: A very great happiness, take my Word for't, Friend; Children bring a great Honour with them, Courtine: It may grow up to be a Comfort to thee in thy old Age, Man.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Oh, Your Olive Branches are unspeakable Blessings, the Gift of Heaven. I love to see Posterity go forward, and Families increase, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let me be hang'd and quarter'd, Gentlemen, if ever I set Eyes on the Harlot in my life before. My sweet Wife, with a Pox to her brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Why, Is thy Wife in London?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, Hell confound her! she has hunted me full Cry up to Town; seiz'd upon me this Morning, and brought me hither, where it seems she lay all the last night.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Why then, for ought I know, we may be still enchanted.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that, with all my heart. Is she in the House?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
No; I was forced to counterfeit sickness, 'till I was e'en sick indeed, to get rid of her, upon pretence of going to my Physitian, in the Devil's name, that this confounded Bulker, with her Guts full of Bastard, and I might console
together for half an hour; and I am sweetly fitted with a Concubine that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: This comes of your Whoring, Courtine; if you had kept me company, and liv'd vertuously, none of this had happened to you now. But you must be wandring: No reasonable iniquity will serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well, I'll swear, Captain Courtine, you are the happiest Gentleman! Yonder's the finest chopping Boy for you. Why, it will be able to carry a Musquet in your Company within this Fortnight. And then, I am so obliged to you for bringing the Lady to lye in at my House, that if your Wife will do me the honour, I'll take it for a favour to stand for Godmother with her.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And, Madam, to return your Complement, I wish with all my heart you were pregnant with a Litter of nine such chopping Boys, upon condition that I were bound to be Godfather to the whole Kennel.— Confound your being witty, with a Plague to you.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: That's something course though, Friend, to a Lady that's so civil to you.

div.stage: Enter several Maids of the Family, one with the Child.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: See Ienny, Yon's the Man; that, that's the Father.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: I'll swear it is a proper person.

sp.speaker: 3. Maid.
sp.p: Oh Sir, Heavens bless you, you're the happiest Man! Here is my young Master, as like you as if you had bore it your self.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: What a pretty little Nose it has!

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: And just its Father's Eyes for all the World.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: It would never grieve a Body to have a Child by such a handsom Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ye Whores! ye Drabs! ye fulsom, slinking Whores! Clusters of Poxes on ye, and no Hospitals pity ye!— Confound ye, leave me.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Fye upon it, Courtine; fye for shame: give something to the Nurse, Man; that's but civil.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: A Bastard! Death, a Bastard! Under my Nose too! Where's the vile hateful Monster?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Have patience, Lady.—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: False, loathsom Traytor.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now my Joy's compleated.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Let me come at him, let me go.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Hold her fast, Friend, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Thou Devil!— Thou treach'rous, faithless, perjur'd Wretch● Thou Husband! Look in my Face.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Well.—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Did I e'er deserve this?
Degenerate Brute! Thou, only in Falshood, Man.
Thou rampant Goat abroad, and Drone at home.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
(Sings)
Like a Dog with a Bottle, &c.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Thou perfect Yoke-fellow! Thou heavy Ox,
That want'st a Goad to make thee know thy strength!
Death, Fiends and Torments! I could dig those Eyes out!

I'll bear't no longer:
Bedlam! Bedlam! Bedlam
!

div.stage: Court. sings, and dances a Iigg.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: No more! I'll stay no more to be his Triumph.
Be warn'd by me, ye Virgins that are blest
With your first native Freedom; let no Oaths
Of perjur'd Mankind wooe ye to your Ruin.
But when a creeping, fawning, weeping Crocodile
Moans at your feet, remember then my Fall:
And when for pity most his Tears implore,
Like me, your Vertue to your Hearts recall;
Resolve to seorn, and never see him more.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: With all my heart, thou dear, dear Wife and Plague.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Methinks a very pitiful Case, this, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If your Widow were but here, Sir, now, she might fairly see what she is like to trust to.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Oh Madam, Madam! What will become of us all?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Become of us, Woman! Prithee, what's the matter? are we in any danger?

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Only your Brother in Law, Madam, and his Friend, with about a dozen Armed Men more, Madam; that's all the matter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Brother in Law!

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Yes, your Brother in Law, Lady, if your Name be Porcia: such a one they ask for.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Porcia!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, Porcia: I could have told you she was Porcia before.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: 'Tis but too true, Sir; my unhappy Name is Porcia.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Porcia, my Widow! my dear lovely Widow! What an ill natur'd trick was this Concealment!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.l: Though, Sir, you never saw my Face before,
If now you think it worth your least Regard,
Protect me; for I dread my Brother's Fury,
Ev'n worse than Matrimony. Here, Sir, I yield my self▪
Up yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: And shall I claim thee?

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.l: From this Hour, for ever.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: And, by this happy Hour, I'll keep thee mine then.
Secure thy self in the next private Closet.
Peace to thy Heart, poor Widow.
Give us but Arms!—

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Those I've provided for you.
I found our Swords in a certain private Corner that shall be nameless, where I was proposing some civil Familiarities to the Lady Governess of the Family, just as the Blusterers entred.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Are they in the House, then?

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Yes, and have bound the Servants too; the hungry Rogues were all surpris'd at Dinner; you'll hear more of them presently, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Stand to your Arms, Beaugard; the Enemy's upon us.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: We have had a Succession of very pretty Adventures here; first we are enchanted, then we are fiddled to sleep, then we are fiddled up again: Then here's a Discovery of a very fair Lady followed by another, of a bouncing brown Bastard; and when we might have thought all Fortunes Tricks had been over, we are in a very fair way at last of having our Throats cut: But I'll secure one life that shall be my care.—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Dog, stay and fight, or, by Heaven, I'll rip your Heart out.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Well then, if I must fight I must: What a Pox, I have two good Seconds o' my side; and that has sav'd many a Cowards Credit before now.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Break open the Door there, force the Passage, down with it.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, what farther? What means this Violence here?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, that's no Secret, when you see who we are.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: We come, Sir, to demand a Lady, Sir; one Porcia.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: How's that, my Father!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Father me no Fathers: I am none of thy Father, Fellow; but I am these Gentlemens Friend here.— Now, Atheist, will I murder thee.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Oh Law'd!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
Iack, Iack, Iack
! Come hither Iack; a word with thee, Iack: Give me a hundred Pieces now, and I'll be o' thy side Iack; and help thee to beat off these impudent Fellows. Gentlemen, I cannot but own to you that this is my Son.—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Sir, were you nick'd to your Shirt, I would not part with a single Shilling, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Though, if he were my Son ten thousand times, in such a Cause as yours, I'd draw my Sword against him.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: You may remember, Gentlemen, a Challenge.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Which you forgot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Hah! A Challenge, Beaugard?

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: I'll tell thee more hereafter. To shew you I ha' not forgot it, the Lady you thus persecute is now under my Protection, and with my Sword I'll keep her so.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If we don't, may my Life get the better of me, and wear mine for a Bodkin.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Come on then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: For the Lady.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: For my Honour.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And for my Friend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Old Brimstone-Beard, have at thee.

div.stage: Fight, The rest of Theodore's Party fall in.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Base Traytors! Odds!

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Confound 'em, thrust.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Oh, I am slain! My Maw runs out: What will become of me! Oh!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Secure that Passage now:— How fares my Friend?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I'm wounded: send for a Chyrurgion quickly, for I bleed much.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Look to your Master, Sirrah; and you, Fellow, be careful of this Beast here.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.p: Oh, a Parson! a Parson! dear Sir, a Parson! Some pious good Divine, if you have any Charity.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Here, here she is: I ha' got her for you; let me alone for ferreting a Female's Quarters out.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I'd have you, Sir, take care for your Security: There's mischief done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: The more mischief the better; thou shalt find me no Flincher, Boy: here, here; make sure of her.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Inhumane Tyrant! Why am I abus'd thus? Help! Murder! Help!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: None of your Tricks; no Cries, no Shrieks for Succour:
By Hell, here's that shall silence you for ever.
Thou Woman! Thou young, itching, wanton Devil!
Fly to base Cells of Lust! Give up thy Vertue,
Disgrace thy Name, and triumph ev'n in Infamy.
On what a tott'ring Point his Honour stands,
That trusts the Treasure in such lavish hands.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter Lucrece in Man's Cloaths, and Chloris.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: FRom this gay minute farewell Love and Doating: I have shook the lazy, stretching, wishing Folly out of my Blood, and now my wandring Heart is at home again. Let me see; I have a hundred and a hundred times wish'd my self a Man; and now, in outward appearance, I am a very Fellow; nay, a very pretty Fellow: for, methinks Foppery, Impertinence, Self-conceit, and other Masculine Qualities grow upon me strangely.— Oh, Mischief, Mischief, Mischief! thou art a very sweet-Employment:— But Opportunity! Bewitching, Lovely, Omnipotent Opportunity! How shall I come at thee? Chloris!—

sp.speaker: Chloris.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Give me my Sword.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: Here Madam: Bless us, What will your Ladyship do with your self in this Equipage!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Ladyship, Huzzy! take notice from this important Moment, I am no more your Mistress; but that Imperial Creature, your Master: and therefore know too, I will have my Foeminine Habiliments burnt instantly, and an Operator sent for to make me a Beard grow. I will learn to Ride, Fence, Vault, and make Fortifications in Dirt-Pyes: Nay, if the humour hold, I'll go Voluntier into Germany against the Turk.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: But what will be the end of all this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Why, if I go into the War, I shall have the privilege, when I return home, to talk of Marches, Battels and Sieges, which I never was at, nor understand any more than the Fools I tell my story to. If I stay at home, with the privilege of good Cloaths, Pertness and much Simplicity, will I set up for a Spark, grow familiar at White-Hall, and impudent with some great Man there or another; run in Debt with a high Hand, be terrible in eating Houses, and noisy all over the Town.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: A very hopeful Resolution.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: As thus: When I and another Spark meet; Dam me, Iack, says I▪ What Times are there stirring? What ready to be had? What Caravans have you met with, or what Loose lately managed? You Rogue, you look very high upon the Huckle.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: Well Madam; But what will all this Gibberish signifie?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Signifie, you Fool! why what it signifies already; Wit, Courage, Martial Discipline, Interest at Court, Pretence to Preferment, Free Quarters in my Lodgings, and Free Booty in every Cuckold's Shop, who shall trust me against his palpable knowledge, that I'm not worth a Groat; and never have the Impudence to hope to be paid.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: And must your Honour have a Mistress too?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p:
Yes Huzzy, and you shall be serviceable to me in the matter: I'll have a Doxy this very Night; I have singled her out already; Courtin's Wife, that jealous, raging, insatiable Help-meet of the Captains shall be my
Ducinea del Toboso
. She's in Love with me already, that's my comfort: as I passed through the Hall just now, she coming into the House to pay a Visit to the Widow Porcia, (who, by the way, is as wicked as my self, and my great Councellor in this noble Project) we met: I, you must know, bow'd very respectfully; she taking me for a Stranger, Curt ' sy'd as low; and viewing me strictly leer'd at me, as if that Minute she took Aim at my Heart, and designed me for her Quarry.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: But, Madam, she knows, and must discover you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Thou art a fool: she never saw me till yesterday in her life-time, then too disguised: So that if I do not practise on her frailty, and by that means find a way to revenge my self on that Vizard-monger Beaugard, may I be condemn'd to wear Breeches as long as I live, and never know more than the present use I make of them.

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: Hist Madam, she's returning.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Hush then: now my Cause is coming▪ on, and have at her.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, pray oblige me so far to shew me the way to the Gardens; I come to pay a Visit to Madam Porcia, and am informed she's gone there for the Air.— A very handsom Youth—

sp.speaker: Chlor.
sp.p: Madam, this young Gentleman here is come hither on the same kind Errand with your Ladyship, and waits till her Return.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: But, Madam, the good fortune of seeing you is a happiness would recompence the being disappointed of all the Conversation of your Sex besides.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Are you a Relation to this Family, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Madam, the greatest Advantage I hope from the Family is, henceforth to have oftner the Honour of kissing your fair Hands here: It is an Opportunity I should make no Ungentlemanly use of.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Opportunity, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Yes, Opportunity Madam: I am not ashamed to mention so honest a Friend as Opportunity, to one that, by her Years and Beauty, should not, methinks, be a mortal Foe to Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Do you know me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Why, Madam; do I treat you like a Stranger? Know you, by this good Hour, there has not been a Day or Night since I first saw you, that I have thought or dreamt of any thing else. Are not you the Life of a certain swaggering Squire about this Town, who calls himself Captain Courtine?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Yes Sir; such a Friend in a Corner I have, Sir; and what have you to say to him, Sir? I'll swear, a very handsom Youth still.—

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: What, Madam! what I have to say to you, rather than lose you, I would say to him: which is, that I like you, love you, languish for you; and would, with all my Heart, Blood, Spirit and Flesh, ●—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: I'll swear, Sir, I am mightily obliged to you, and so is Mr. Courtine; ha, ha, ha!—

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Mr. Courtine! Take notice, Madam, I receive that Expression as kindly as if you had called him what I wish him: for, pretty one, if my Intelligence be true, he lives with your Ladyship as much like Mr. Courtine, as much like a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Oh Gaud! he's very handsom.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Shall we walk in these Gardens anon, for I have the privilege of a Key that opens into the Fields: The Moon shines too.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Between Ten and Eleven does the Moon shine?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: As bright as any thing but your self.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: But you'll tell, young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Only you how I love you.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Eleven's a late Hour.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Not too late.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Take this, and my Word for it.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Fye, how you use me, when you mean to forget me.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Hush, no more; Company's coming. Eleven.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Ten if you are kind enough.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Well said, my chast Sex.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Oh Cousin, art thou come! Thou art the welcomest Creature on the Earth; I have expected thee almost to despair for these three Hours. Oh, Sir! your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I am here, Madam, in order to your Commands.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Her Commands!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Oh, Cousin, the prettiest best natur'd Youth! He is something related to us a great way off; and by that means has the privilege of Visiting, without offence to my jealous Brother in Law, and Tyrannical Guardian. Have you contriv'd that business?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Madam, it is done.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Bus'ness! What Bus'ness, Cousin?
Lord, Cousin, you seem concern'd at it.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: I'll tell thee: Seeing my self here consin'd to the Rules and Limits of a very Prison, I have resolv'd to put as good a face upon the matter as it will bear, and make my misfortune as easie as I can. Wherefore, for a little present diversion, I have contrived a Letter in an unknown name, by this young Agent here, and convey'd it to thy lewd Husband, with another in my own to Beaugard; and sent for thee, my Dear, to share in the pleasure of the Consequence.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha! But what will be this Consequence, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p:
Twenty to one but it occasions some new Alarm, and Divertisement to my Jaylours; who are so very capricious, they would fancy a Rat behind
the Hangings for a concealed Lover. It may too, by chance, produce me some lucky opportunity once more to make my Escape out of their merciless Power. Nay, they are already half disposed to run away themselves; for by my Womans interest in the Chirurgeon, who has care of the swearing Atheistical Fellow, yesterday hurt in the scuffle, and afterwards conveyed hither, he gives it out, that he fears his Wounds may be mortal. Upon which, my Lover Gratian sighs, and turns up his Eyes like a Godly Brother at Exercise. My Brother Theodoret puffs, swells, grinds his Teeth, and stamps as if he would brain himself against the next Wall; while poor Beaugard's ne'er be good Father has, with pure fear, lost a red Nose that has been his fast Friend for these 40 years; and every time he sees his Face in a Glass, fancies every Wrinkle there has the shape of a Gibbet.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, dear Lady, what will become of us! the most unhappy Accident!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, I could not possibly help it: I ha' lost it.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Lost it, lost what? What hast thou lost? Would thou hadst lost thy self; lost a Leg or an Arm, or any thing, rather than have put me in this fright. Speak, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, the Billet; Madam, the Billet.

sp.speaker: Lucr. Sylv.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: What, the Note I sent to Beaugard?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: As I hope to see you happy, Madam, I put it as fast here between these two poor naked Breasts here, as ever it could stick, so I did, when, just as I was going forth, who should meet me but the old, wicked, ranting, roaring Gentleman that lies hid here for fear of hanging, would he had been well hang'd a Twelvemonth since; and there he fell a towzing, and a mowzing, and a meddling with me; I was never so afraid of being ravish'd in my life, Gad he knows: So in the struggle, I guess the Note was lost truly; though, in my heart, I wish I had been ravish'd six times over, rather than such a misfortune had happened. Nevertheless, I ha' done your bus'ness for you, so I have.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Bus'ness! what Bus'ness? Ugliness and ill Reputation light on thee. Thou hast undone and ruin'd me for ever.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Why, I have met with the Captain, and told him the whole matter, as well as if he had read it in the Letter himself. He's but too kind a Man to you, and I too faithful a Servant, so I am, to be thus reviled and cursed by you, for all this.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: What then did he say? Fool, Beast and Blockhead; tell me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Why, he said, he'd die a thousand and a thousand times for you, were it possible, so he did; and that that he will not eat, drink or sleep●till he has set you at liberty, so he wo'not; and that he will be in the Garden before Ten.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: What's in this Case to be done, Madam?

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p:
O dearest Cousin, retire if you love me; for, should the Lords of my Liberty get any notice of this Billet, and find a Man here, notwithstanding
your Relation, who knows what ill usage it may aggravate!— To thy Chamber, dear Lucrece, e'er the Storm comes upon us,

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I am all Obedience. Sweet Creature, you'll remember!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: It is not possible to forget you, surely.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Blessings on you for this Goodness.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Double Bar up all the Doors and Windows: Load all the Arms in the House, and be ready for Execution instantly, all of ye. By those Devils that dance in your gogling Eyes, Madam, I'll try if you have given, your self over to Hell so far, that you can out at a Key-hole.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: What means the great He Brute?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: To cut off your Intelligence, Lady, and make thee, e'er I have done, to curse thy Father and Mother, that let thee learn to write. Seest thou this! thou irreclamable profligate Wretch! Fogh! Send you the draggle-tail'd Minister of thy lewd Affairs a hunting, full cry about the Town, upon the rank Scent of a Brawny-back'd Hector! By Heavens! the thought of it makes me loath the House, and fancy it stinks of the Soul Sins thou hast imagined in it.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Thou barbarous, ill manner'd, worse than Beast! Why am I abus'd thus? Why made a Prisoner too, at your sawcy Will? Fetter'd up, and barr'd all Liberty and Converse?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: For the same reason other too hot blooded Females are; because, if possible, I would not have a good Breed spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: What a Load of Dirt is the Thick-Skull cram'd withall, if the Tongue were able to throw it out!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Filthy, filthy, fulsom filthy! What, be a Doll-Common, follow the Camp! How lovelily would your fair Ladyship look, mounted upon a Baggage-Cart, presiding over the rest of the Captain's dirty Equipage!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: If any thing in the World would make me follow a Camp, it would be a very strong fancy I have, that I should never see you in one, Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Your Ladyship has reason to defend the Souldiers Cause: You have married one, as I take it, Madam. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: He in a Camp! He has not Courage enough to animate half a Taylor, not good Nature enough to make a Spaniel of, or Sence enough, if he were that Animal, to learn to fetch and carry.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: This will open no Locks, Lady.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: But there are Instruments to be had, that will break open Locks, Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Will you please to retire, and consider farther of that in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: No, I'll not stir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Nay, by Heaven, but you shall, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Nay, by Heaven, but she shall not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: By Iove, and that's well said, I'll stand still a little, and see what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Do not drive me to use Violence.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: How! Violence to a fair Lady! That's not so well, neither.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Heark you, Sir; my Jaylor, or my Hang-man; for which of the two your Office will end in, by your proceedings I cannot imagine: do but touch me, or offer the least force to compel me to a closer Confinement; by this injur'd Heart, I'll fire the House about your Asses Ears: I'll sooner burn with you, to be reveng'd, than endure such Insolence and Torment any longer.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I Gad, a brave Girl, a delicate Wench! How my Fingers itch to take her part now! I have a Months mind to espouse her Quarrel, and make Friends with poor Iacky again. Honest Iacky! 'tis the best natur'd Boy in the World, though I was such a Beast to fall out with him.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Inhumane, cruel Theodoret! Why do you afflict me thus? Why do you force the Tears from my poor Eyes, and wrack a tender Heart that never wrong'd you?—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: For your Souls Health, Lady; and the Welfare of your wasting Reputation. A Pox o'your Whining! Come, to your Chamber, to your Prayer-Book and Repentance: Fasting and Humiliation will be good for you. To your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: To my Grave first.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Nay then— Wha, hoa!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Stand off! Murder! Cramps, Rheums and Palsies, wither thy unmanly Hands.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: By Heav'n!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: You dare not do't.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Sylvia.
sp.p: No Sir, you dare not do't, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p:
Avaunt Pass
! Confound me, but I shall be scratch'd here presently for my patience.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: What an ill bred Camel 'tis!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Nay, and what's more; you shall not do't, you shall not; Sir Hoh! Is this the Issue of your honourable Pretensions?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Et tu Brute!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Brute, Brute! Brute me no Brutes Friend: Oonds I am a Man, Fellow; Battoons and Bilboes! Brute! a Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Don't pardon him, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Gratian leaning on a Staff.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Oh, Friend!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Poor Gratian.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: If ever we ought to do any thing for our Safety, let us now prepare, and look about us: I have made hard shift to hobble hither, my Wound's grown very troublesom▪— We are all lost.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I can fear nothing when my Friend's so near me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Now Cousin rebel, and force your Freedom nobly.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Iacky, I hope. Iacky at the Head of Mirmidons, and declaring for his Property. Look you, Gentlemen; I must confess, I have Remorse of Conscience, and am sensible I have been a Rebel: wherefore, if my Liege Son and Heir have recruited his Power, and be once more up in Arms, Loyalty and Natural Affection, Friends, will work, I must pronounce for Prince Iacky; and here I resolve to defend his Territories.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: If Prince Iacky have Interest enough to get your Pardon for Murder, Sir, it will be your best way to close with him; for, in short, the Atheist Dardevill, your Antagonist, is dead Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Hah! Dead!

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Gratian.
sp.p: Yes dead, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: So much the better. Porcia, let us run up to the Leads, and cry out Murder to the Streets this Moment.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Then I find that I am but a short liv'd Sinner; farewell for ever old Hock, Sherry, Nutmeg and Sugar, Seven and Eleven; Sink-Tray, and the Doublets! Never comes better of rebleting against one's natural born Children. I shall be hanged one of these Sun-shiny Mornings, and a Ballad come out in the Afternoon to a lamentable Eighty eight Tune of the careful Son, and prodigal Father. Dead said you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Or, at least, cannot survive half an Hour; therefore it is my Opinion that we instantly quit the House, and provide all for our Safety.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Confusion, Devils!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: Nay, Sir; stand fast! dare but to open a Door, Sir; by Heav'n, that Moment I'll alarm the Town: you shall not think to escape, reeking with a poor Man's Blood, shed in defence of me.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Lady, no fooling.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: No Sir, no fooling: but now, Sir, do you to your Chamber, Sir, to your Chamber; to your Prayer-Book and Repentance; Fasting and Humiliation will be good for you: To your Chamber, Sir; as you tender your Neck, Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Damnation! Unhand me!

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: I'll dye e'er I'll unhold you. Think you so barb'rously to leave me here in the House with a dead Wretch, and have the Punishment of his horrid Murder light on my innocent Head.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: What do you resolve to do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Do, Sir! What can I resolve to do, Sir? I have no means to hope to escape, Sir: for, in the first place, I have no Money; and a Man that kills another, without Money in his pocket, is in a very hopeful condition. In the next place, for a disguise, I have no Cloaths but these you see on my Back; with this Tripe-Buff Belt here, which there is not a Constable in the whole City but knows, and has had in his Custody, Sword and all. Look you, Gentlemen, I have civilly kill'd a Man for your Service; if you will resolve, fairly and squarely, to hang like Friends together, so: If not, I mutiny; and the word is, Discover the Plot, the old Boy must impeach.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! where are you?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Well, Rosard; what's the News now?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The Gentleman, Heav'n be thanked, is reviv'd again, Sir; though the Doctors say, such another Fit will certainly carry him off. The poor Creature is very weak, but very penitent.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: In troth, and that's a very ill Symptom; therefore my Opinion is still— I am for hanging all together.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Heark you, old Rust; you say you have no Money, wherefore, during the present Interval, in the first place, because I will have no Mutiny upon this occasion; in order to your Escape, there's Money for you: in the next place, as you want Change of Rayment, here is the Key of a small Wardrobe, at the lower end of the Gallery above, you'll find the Door to it: Equip your self, and provide for your Security, as your best Discretion shall direct you.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Look you, Friend, the sooner the better; for, to tell you the truth, else I shall make but a scurvy matter of it at Tyburn Cross; with a whining, snivling Account of breaking the Sabbath, and keeping ill Company. Wherefore, not being good at making Speeches, I will leave the Opportunity to you, of shewing your politer Rhetorick, and save a Member of the Common-wealth— There's no great harm in Murder, when it brings a Man Money.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p: And now, my Tyrant Brother, I hope we stand on even Terms.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No, Lady, not yet: There's Life return'd, and therefore hopes still, though, at present, in some measure to comply with you, and ease your Apprehensions, within the Limits of the House and Gardens you are at your Liberty, but no farther this Night: And, for your ampler satisfaction, if I have any Midnight Alarms from your Correspondent abroad, there's Entertainment ready for him, which he may not be very fond of; so Good Night, it is almost Ten. Who waits? What hoa, be ready there. Come Gratian, I'll see you to your Repose, and then to my Post of Guard.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p:
Ten! That was the Hour,
Phillis, Beaugard
mentioned; was it not?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: It was, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pore.
sp.p:
Be ready then, all ye propitious Powers, that smile on faithful Love; Wait, like kind Angels, on him; Establish Conquest in his able Hand, and Kindness in his Heart. Oh,
Sylvia▪

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: You are transported, Cousin!

sp.speaker: Pore.
sp.p: With hopes of Liberty I am indeed: it is an English Woman's natural Right. Do not our Fathers, Brothers and Kinsmen often, upon pretence of it, bid fair for Rebellion against their Soveraign; And why ought not we, by their Example, to rebel as plausibly against them?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: Most edifying Doctrine this is, truly.

sp.speaker: Porcia.
sp.p:
The Sign! Heark, the Sign! Phillis, heard you nothing?
[Whistle again.
'Tis there again; he's true, and I am happy. Sylvia, let us retire our selves; you know your old Apartment, for pretious mischief will be soon on foot; and Action worthy Love's great Cause. Thy Husband too, may chance to
have his share in the bus'ness; and, as I have order'd Matters, meet something in the Adventure, to mortifie his roving Humour, and reconcile him to his Duty and Allegiance.— Heark:
[Whistle again.
There, 'tis once more a Summons to the Citadel to surrender. This shall, in after Story, be call'd, Captain Beaugard's besieging of the Widow.
sp.l: Which, as 'tis laid sure, with Success must end,
Since Justice does his Enterprize attend
Without, and powerful Love within's his Friend.

div.stage: SCENE changed to Fields on the Back-side of a Garden

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Hold, stand fast; I have just now receiv'd Intelligence over the Garden-Wall, that our design has taken air, and there will be no easie Entrance.

sp.speaker: 1. Man.
sp.p: Ah Captain; the time has been, when, under your Command, we should have had no need of a Council of War for the attacking such a Fortification as this is.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Peace Plunder, Peace you Rogue; no Moroding now: we'll burn, rob, demolish and murder another time together: This is a Bus'ness must be done with Decency.— Heark.

sp.speaker: 2. Man.
sp.p: Some Company coming, Sir, from the Back-Street Ward.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Hold then, Plunder: Do you, with your flying Party, hover at a distance about the Fields; while I, with the rest of the Body, post my self as advantagiously as I can, to watch the Enemies Motions.—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: This way the noise was: Be sure keep safe the Garden Gate, and follow me carefully.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
So, here I am; and now for my Instructions. Let me see.
[Reads the Billet.
Pray come disguised, that if the Design should miscarry, your Retreat may be the easier. Your unknown blushing Servant
— Humph!
Blushing Servant
! Passingly modest, I'll warrant you!
Pray come disguised
! So I am, or the Devil's in't; for I look more like a Cut-throat, than any thing else. Let me see; Upon this very Spot, the last time I was here, did I meet my damn'd Wife: Avert the Omen, sweet Heaven, I beseech thee. And now, as I am considering, where can my Friend Beaugard be at present too? With a Whore. There's that Question answer'd. Wherefore, would but my unknown blushing Servant appear, or give me a kind Sign; would but my little Partridge call, methinks I could so shuckle, and run, and Bill, and clap my Wings about her. Hah!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Stand: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: ● Serv.
sp.p: Stand, Sir: What are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What am, I, Sir! A Man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: A Man, Sir, we see you are: But what Man are you, Friend?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A Gentleman, Friend; and you had best use me so.— By Heaven, Theodoret; and if I am but discover'd!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Hands off, unloose him. You are not him we look for, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I am glad of that with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: And therefore I ask your Pardon. But, if you are a Gentleman, you will assist one in me, that have been injured. I have reason to believe, my House is now beset by Villains, who have base designs upon the Honour of my Family. Wherefore, if you are what you pretend, you'll draw your Sword to do a good Cause Justice.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sir, I wear it for no other end; and you shall command it.— Ay, 'tis so Beaugard; upon new Exploits for the Recovery of his Widow. Nothing but Knight-Errantry stirring this Moon.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Please you then, Sir, to stay here with my Servants, while I walk to the Corner of yon Wall, and try what I can discover.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You may trust me, Sir. Now will I shew my self a true Renegado; take Entertainment in Christian Service, to betray 'em to my Brother Turk, upon the first opportunity. And so, my blushing Unknown, you may e'en stay your Stomach with your Sheets for this Night.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: They are here, stand fast; be resolute, and be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Now, for a convenient Opportunity to do a mischief: Beaugard, I find, is come, and my kind Mistress punctual to Appointment in the Garden. Now, could I but order the Affair so, as to slur Beaugard upon her, instead of my self; and her upon him, instead of Porcia, my Conscience would be satisfied; and he, Mr. Courtine, my Rival Widow, and the Life serv'd all in their kind.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; What are you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ay; Now, now.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: No matter, Sir; this is not a time of Night to answer Questions.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Nay, then.—

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Nay, now Sir; and when else you think fitting, Sir: I am the Man you look for; and you are him I wisht to meet here.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now how the Devil I shall do to tilt Booty; Hang me like a Dog if I can imagine.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.p: Come on there.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: You pass upon your death.

sp.speaker: Beaug.
sp.l: I have learnt to scorn death more since first you threatned it▪
I see your Numbers too, and come prepar'd,
Porcia's my Claim, and here I'll win or lose her.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Then take thy due; and dye like a midnight Thief. Fall on.

div.stage: [Beaug. and Theod. engage, and their Parties. Beaug. and Theod. quit each other. Beaug. falls upon Courtine, and Theod. upon Beaug. Party; who retire from him, ●s Court. does from Beaug. off from the Stage.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: He runs, he runs; the Half-bred Hector runs.
